values.alignmentText: Used in enterprises with solid demand.
Generally good but urban pollution and Saharan dust affect some areas.
Increasingly secular though Catholic traditions remain.
Low; democratic institutions remain strong.
Modern banking and widespread card use.
Famous beaches with warm waters and amenities.
Growing scene with dedicated bars.
Limited public daycare; family networks fill gap.
Playgrounds and public spaces are abundant.
Free preschool (3–6); subsidies/tax deductions for 0–3 vary by region; 16 weeks paid leave per parent; benefits differ by autonomous community.
Residents contributing to social security often access many supports; eligibility and documentation vary by status/region.
Football, fiestas, and outdoor cafes.
Sociable culture with strong community ties.
Need to maintain residency days and paperwork.
Lower than Northern Europe; high in Barcelona and Madrid.
Limited—generally for Ibero-American/Andorra/Philippines/Equatorial Guinea/Portuguese/Brazilian; others often must renounce prior citizenship.
Growing economy but high youth unemployment.
Mixed economy integrated within the EU.
Solid public schools with regional disparities.
Digital nomad and startup visas available with moderate bureaucracy.
Varied ecosystems from Pyrenees to Mediterranean coast.
Moderate income tax with social contributions.
Pleasant shoulder season; ~14–22 C (57–72 F); Atlantic fronts bring rain north; Mediterranean milder longer.
Family-oriented society with close ties.
Family reunification allows work and schooling.
16 weeks paid parental leave each parent; child benefits/tax credits vary by income/region; flexible work gaining ground.
Extended family support common.
Many benefits tied to residence/contributions; access varies by status and region; employer policies important.
Casual chic to minimalist; dresses/skirts with layers; seasonally appropriate footwear; strong style culture in cities.
Mediterranean smart-casual; linen/cotton in summer; clean sneakers/loafers; layered outerwear in cooler months.
Fashionable but diverse expressions.
Growing industry in Barcelona and Madrid.
Legal recognition and social support.
Strong legal framework for gender equality.
Evolving toward equality though machismo persists.
NIE/TIE, padron, social security; public healthcare access for residents (contributory or convenio especial); private insurance for others; driver licence exchange depends on origin.
Heatwaves and drought are increasing concerns.
Universal, high-quality public system.
Access via residency; private insurance initially.
Low public tuition vs US; scholarships (becas MEC); strong universities in Madrid/Barcelona/Valencia/Granada.
International tuition higher; scholarships limited but exist; options improve with EU/PR status.
Rising rents in major cities; affordable elsewhere.
PAYE plus annual filings with regional variations.
Free public/semi-private (concertado) system; secular public schools; quality varies by region/district; bilingual options in many areas.
Resident children generally enroll in public schools; documentation needed; Spanish-as-second-language supports available.
Spanish required; English moderate in cities.
Among Europe's most LGBTQ-friendly nations.
Left-wing parties active with historical context.
Traditional machismo fading; family involvement increasing.
Active expat and tech meetups.
Rising but still moderate.
Modern cities with high-speed rail and fiber internet.
Historic cities and scenic landscapes abound.
Earthquake risk in south and occasional floods.
Mountains, beaches, and rural getaways accessible.
Renowned nightlife and music festivals.
Late dining and vibrant nightlife in Madrid/Barcelona/Valencia; smaller cities/towns quieter; generally safe, family-friendly evenings.
Events like Gamelab Barcelona foster networking.
MercurySteam and Tequila Works located here.
Regional grants and incubators support startups.
Relaxed, especially in smaller towns.
Late bedtimes and strong family involvement.
Ten-year residency; dual citizenship limited.
Moderate but improving.
Parliamentary monarchy with regional autonomy.
Limited acceptance; urban areas more tolerant.
Escuela infantil (0–3) mix of public/subsidized/private; preschool (3–6) free; availability varies by city/region; waitlists in big metros.
Concertado (low fees, often religious) and fully private/international (higher fees) concentrated in major cities.
Progressive social policies post-democracy.
Public broadcasters promote national unity.
Free press with some regional media bias.
Good urban transit and extensive rail network.
Secular state with minimal religious influence.
Remote work embraced during pandemic and for nomads.
Temporary residency leading to permanent after five years.
Contributory state pension (edad de jubilacion rising); adequacy depends on contributions/housing; private savings helpful.
Pension access after contributions; popular for retirees.
Eligibility/portability based on residence and contributions; totalization agreements may help; private savings advisable.
Startup hubs in Madrid and Barcelona use Ruby.
Low violent crime; petty theft in tourist areas.
Public, concertado, and international schools available.
Comfortable swimming from late spring through fall.
Hot summers and mild winters with wetter north.
Open attitudes with sex education present.
Progressive on LGBTQ and healthcare.
Mild; Atlantic north ~10–16 C (50–61 F), Mediterranean coasts warmer; showers common; increasing sun.
Generally stable though regional independence tensions exist.
Social market economy with welfare programs.
Market economy with regulation.
Coasts warm/dry ~22–30 C (72–86 F); interior (Madrid/Andalucia) often >35 C (95 F) with low humidity; nights hot inland.
Processing moderate with bureaucratic delays.
Moderate trust affected by corruption scandals.
Political and housing-related scandals.
Lower than Northern Europe but cost of living is lower too.
Family meals, plazas/parks, beach/hiking; retail open Sat and Sun hours vary; festivals and late dinners common.
Primary often ~09:00–14:00 with afternoon activities; secondary ~08:30–15:00; offices ~09:00–18:00 with lunch; later evenings common.
30 calendar days required.
August shutdowns provide extended holidays.
Friendly with EU neighbors; occasional rivalry with Portugal.
Proud of regional identities and national heritage.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Seen as warm and lively.
Digital nomad and non-lucrative visas available.
Positive attitude with growing expat communities.
Vibrant culture, food, and festivals.
Coasts mild ~8–15 C (46–59 F); interior cooler with frosts; snow in mountains (Pyrenees/Sierra Nevada); damp chill in north.
40-hour week with flexible schedules in some sectors.
Strong culture of leisure and siesta tradition.
Strong labor laws and unions.
